She began purchasing products from the Ukraine and selling them in her hometown over a year ago and has had loyal customers ever since. She keeps her stand open almost every day, together with friends who help her by staying at her table when she needs to leave, and most of that time a customer or two is also there. Svetlana now needs a loan to buy a bulk shipment of products at a favorable price 

*employee and customer pictured

loans.use: Purchasing cosmetics and perfume in bulk quantities.

loans.name: Kulsum

texts.en:
Kulsum is a member of MBK who has requested a second loan of $100. The loan from MBK will be partially used to fund weaving bamboo basket and the balance for her husband’s fan and basket weaving trade. 5 large and 10 small baskets can be woven from a stalk of bamboo costing IDR7,000. These baskets can be sold for IDR6,000 and IDR3,500 for the large and small baskets, respectively.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Bamboo basket - Bakul Bambu

loans.name: Samanta Vanessa

texts.en:
Ms. Samanta has been a distributor of cheeses and sausages for one year. "I am a single mother and I have dedicated myself to distributing cheese and sausage, which my family sends to me from the city of San Pedro, Coahuila, in order to support my children, but I have very little money invested and I would like to invest more in order to have more earnings. I am requesting $1,000.00 for this investment."

<Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To invest in the business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica A. hails from the new Amuru district in northern Uganda and has been living in Kampala for the past 10 years. She has been her family's primary income earner for the past few years with her husband suffering ill health due to attacks by rebels while still in the war zone of northern Uganda.

Through her hard work, she managed to set up a small retail shop with her first Kiva loan, which she obtained through LiA. To date, she has only made one late loan payment. Her shop has been doing well and through it she has managed to pay fees for her children and buy some household items.

She however feels that she can do better by adding more stock to the shop. In this way she can even supply her clients who always pay at the end of month, so she will not run out of stock even if she is still waiting for them to pay. In order to do this she needs more money to restock the shop especially with sugar and maize flour, which are her most popular items.

She therefore seeks a loan of $150 in to buy more items for her shop. She will be able to repay this loan in 4 months

Below is her budget in full: (The individual items are listed in Ugandan shillings and the total has been converted to US$)

1-sugar 2 bags @ 80,000/= ---------- 160,000/=

2- maize flour 50kgs 2bags @ 35,000/= ---- 70,000/=

3- transport ----------- 20,000/=

Total ----------- 250,000/= ($150)

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop

loans.name: Blanca Alicia

texts.es:
Blanca Alicia tiene 40 años de edad y tiene dos hijos, ellos son originarios de la localidad de Escobedo, Nuevo León. Blanca es una mujer emprendedora que se ha esforzado mucho para sacar adelante a su familia ella sola, hace seis años inició su propio negocio con la venta de papelería, donde recibe la ayuda de su hijo menor, de 18 años de edad, afortunadamente sus clientes se han incrementado y ahora ha incorporado la venta de productos naturales, obteniendo una muy buena respuesta de sus clientes.

En estos momentos Blanca necesita un préstamo de $ 550 que empleará en la compra mercancía para continuar creciendo con su negocio, con esto Blanca espera poder ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes y cubrir sus necesidades, ella promete regresar esta cantidad en 6 meses. Forma parte importante en el desarrollo de este negocio, y ayuda a esta familia, ellos te lo agradecen sinceramente.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is planning to get engaged with a very sweet girl. Even though he owns a barber shop, he still needs a loan to help him pay for the fees of his engagement. Mohamad is 23 years old and would do anything to be able to marry this woman of his dreams and is certain that his work would guarantee his repayments. Mohamad is driven by a great amount of love which clearly makes him more confident that, in his future, he will continue to be happy both personally and in business. We wish him all the best.

loans.use: For his engagement expenses

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en:
This is Sifa M. who runs a shop, selling a variety of clothing in downtown Dar. She is 42 years old and married to Samuel with whom she has three children, Minaeli, 23, Angela, 20, and Yonaza, 15. She has operated her shop since 2006 and requires a loan of $275 to purchase new stock, which she will sell at a profit. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Sonqollay Group

texts.en:
“Sonqollay”, which means “my heart” in quechua, is a new communal bank which was started with 17 associates. Some of these members were members of other communal banks before.

The associates start to save with an initial deposit of 100, 150, or 200 soles. They then receive a loan which will be invested in their business. The associates work in different types of businesses such as: selling chicken, groceries, fish, cattle, meat, ice cream, bread, food, weaving, and transportation.

Each associate has a different history that they can tell. One example is Liz, who has a small grocery store. She started with only a small amount of capital; with this loan, she will be able to expand her business. On the other hand, Maura is an artisan. She weaves beautiful tapestries and wall hangings. She learned this art from her parents when she was very young. Maura was invited to join this bank by her sister who is a member of another communal bank. Maura hopes to export her tapestries and constantly innovate her art. Meanwhile, Haydee makes ice cream. She started her business with a manual machine; with her savings, she was able to buy an automatic ice cream maker.

The associates need loans of different sizes. Some need 300, 450, or 600 soles reaching a total of 6000 soles in loans from the communal bank. (1USD = almost 3 Peruvian soles). They will invest these loans in buying things such as sugar, milk, beans, rice, fish, soap, flower, butter, animals, wood, and dyes which are necessary for their businesses. Their dreams are to have their own land, house, or business, and for their children to be professionals and improve their economic standing.

loans.use: The associates will invest these loans in buying things such as sugar, milk, beans, rice, fish, soap, flower, butter, animals, wood, and dyes which are necessary for their businesses.

loans.name: Namugongo B Group

texts.en: The group leader of this small group is Sylvia N..  She is currently in the business of matooke selling and is requesting a loan of UGX 10,00,000 to invest in the business.  Sylvia is 42 years old and is a widow.    She has 5 children ranging from age 12 to to 18 and her children go to school.  Each week, Sylvia makes approximately UGX 60,000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to to save money for her childrens' eduction  Sylvia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300,000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.  Sylvia is joined in her small group by Ritah B., Rose Namuyinbwa, Agnes N., and Damalie N..  Ritah B. currently runs a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to increase the stock of products in the shop.  Rose N. is currently in the business of used clothing and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to purchase more clothes for sale.  Agnes N. is currently in the business of matooke selling and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to expand and become a wholesaler.  Damalie N. is currently runs a stationary shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to buy a photcopying machine.

loans.use: To expand matooke business

loans.name: Paula

texts.en:
Paula is from the community of Rumichaca, which is located 15 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. She has been a member of the community bank Rumichaca for six months. One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Paula plans to use her savings to buy a milk cow. Her dream is to have a large well stocked store and to raise animals like she did before.

Paula is 58 years old. She is a widow and has ten children, only one of whom lives with her. Paula has a store located in her home, where she sells food staples such as flour, rice, and sugar. Paula and her son work together to grow cilantro, carrots, and parsley, which they sell in the market in Ayacucho.

In addition, Paula has four hectares of land, where she harvests wild fruit such as tuna, cochinilla, and tara. In the past, Paula raised animals; she hopes to start this business again soon.

Paula needs a loan of $525, which she will use to buy sugar, milk, oil, rice, a cow and a bull.

loans.use: To buy sugar, milk, oil, rice, a cow and a bull

loans.name: Roxana

texts.es:
In one of the most concurred avenues of the city of Juliaca we find a very happy and laborious lady named Roxana, a 33-year-old, offering departmental transport service tickets to the population of her city. Roxana is a young lady who has a very low income, but this fact has not discourage her to succeed in life and to try to do well next to her elderly parents. Besides offering transportation tickets, Roxana has a small store selling basic supplies and groceries. Roxana’s mother takes care of the store while she works during the day. Roxana would like to purchase more merchandise in order to expand her business and increase her profits and in this manner offer her parents a better living. "Your important contribution will help Roxana attain her goals."

Translated from Spanish by Antonella Sacconi, Kiva Volunteer.

En una de las avenidas más concurridas de la ciudad de Juliaca encontramos muy contenta y afanosa a Roxana de 33 años de edad, ofreciendo sus boletos de servicio de transporte departamental a la población de su ciudad.Roxana es una joven de bajos recursos económicos, pero este hecho no la amilanó para esforzarse en la vida y tratar de salir adelante junto a sus ancianos padres, ahora adicionalmente de ofrecer boletos de transporte tiene una pequeña tienda de insumos de primera necesidad, tiendita que atiende su querida madre mientras Roxana desde tempranas horas de la mañana se va a ofrecer los boletos.El deseo de Roxana es aumentar el stock de mercadería de su bodeguita con el fin de obtener mayores beneficios económicos para ofrecerles tranquilidad y seguridad a sus queridos padres.“Vuestra importante colaboración concretará los anhelos de Roxana”

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Tumaini

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Tumaini K.. She is married and has 2 children aged 1 and 8. She has 3 dependents who live with her because they are relatives. In 2004, Tumaini established her rice-selling business. She is now requires a loan in order to buy more stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilitation as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment—a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more stock in bulk.

loans.name: Jonnex

texts.en: M. Jonnex is a fisherman at the Katosi fish landing. He has been fishing ever since he left school some years back, and he does not regret it. He owns a boat with which he earns a living for his family. He is asking for a loan through his Kewerimidde group to help him do his fishing job better.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and hooks

loans.name: Block B North B 2031-5 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Rejoice L.. She sells sorgurm and is requesting a loan to pay school fees. Rejoice is 42 years old and married to a shopkeeper. She has five children, ranging from age 9 to 24, all of whom go to school. Each week, Rejoice makes approximately 200 Sudanese pounds in profit, and with the extra capital from her loan she hopes to be able to pay school fees.

Rejoice is joined in her small group by Lusia J., Foyiba F., Eva S., and Elizabeth M.. Lusia sells vegetables at the market and wants to open up a shop. Foyiba sells groudnut paste at the market and wants a loan to expand her business. Eva sells charcoal and wants to expand the business. Elizabeth sells dry fish at the market and is requesting a loan to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To pay school fees.

loans.name: Fatuma's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is a 34-year-old, married woman with 2 children (aged 13 and 2 years old). She began selling foods in 2008. Every day, she works from 1 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $18 from her sales.

Fatuma now requests a loan in order to buy more food items, such as rice, maize, flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Zubeda and Magreth, who also have businesses dealing with poultry and fish sales.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional food items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy palm oil, piglets and seeds.

loans.name: Dembe Lending Group

texts.en:
Robinah N. is the leader of Dembe Women's Group, which has been in existence for 5 years. She is a married woman and works with her husband for the benefit of their family. Robinah has 2 businesses. She is a farmer growing mostly bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes as well as making local alcohol for sale to bars around her home and to those in town centers.

The local brews she makes are waragi and tonto. She prepares spear grass that is mixed with the ripe juice of bananas (mabidde). The juice that comes out is put into jerry cans and sorghum is mixed in. The cans are put in a previously dug hole and covered for a week or two and the end result is tonto. For waragi, the tonto is again put into metal cans and placed on a fire with a tube that connects to two more metal cans from which the boiled tonto moves and is cooled. In a week, Robinah can make and sell 8 jerry cans of tonto and 7 of waragi for wholesale as she also sells it to her daily customers that drink it at her home. Robinah needs a loan to be able to buy more bananas and pay labor for collecting the grass for her local brew business.

loans.use: Buy more bananas and pay labor for collecting the grass for her local brew business.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Maribel inicio el negocio hace 4 años porque necesitaba ayudar a su marido en la economía familiar ya que el trabaja por su cuenta y en ocasiones no tiene trabajo, por lo cual ella ingreso con sus vecinas a la venta de ropa y con eso tiene un ingreso para cuando su esposo este sin trabajo no verse tan apretados económicamente.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para poder invertir en mas ropa para incrementar las ventas.
texts.en:
Maribel started her business four years ago becuase she neeeded to help her husband with family expenses. Her husband is only able to work occassionally, which is why she works with her neighbors selling clothing. With this work she has income for the times when her husband is without work so that they are not so squeezed economically. She needs a loan for $400, which she will repay in 6 months, in order to invest in more clothing so she can increase sales.


Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana S., from Surallah South Cotabato City, is the mother of seven and an entrepreneur who has always dreamed of a better life for her family. A CEV client for four years already, Feliciana used the loan she previously received from CEV to start her own rattan furniture business. Accommodating the schools, her friends and other people, she has been able to firmly establish her business and provide for all her family’s needs.

Feliciana is now requesting another loan in order to purchase furniture materials. In an interview she said that she wants to add more displays of sofas, dividers, and beds to her store so as to attract more customers and increase her sales volume. An improved income will allow her to send all of her children to college. “As a mother, all I want for my children is for them to finish their studies and live a comfortable life,” she added.

loans.use: To purchase furniture materials

loans.name: Do Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Đỗ Thị Trọng năm nay 32 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007. Vòng vốn đầu chị vay 3.000.000đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi gà. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang nuôi khoảng 1000 con gà thịt và gà đẻ trứng  cho thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn  tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để mua cám, thức ăn phục vụ cho công việc chăn nuôi gà.
texts.en:
Mrs. Đỗ Thị Trọng is 32 years old. She has been participating in the TYM Fund since 2007. Her first loan was for 3,000,000 VND which she invested into raising chicken. Today, her family is raising about 1,000 meat-producing chicken and egg-laying hens which produce an income of 5,000,000 VND per month. For this loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND to purchase bran, as feed for the chicken.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising chicken.

loans.name: Neida Martina

texts.es: DOÑA MARTINA QUE CUENTA CON 35 AÑOS VIVE EN SU PROPIA CASA UBICADA EN LA COMUNIDAD DE AZUZAQUI, JUNTO A SU ESPOSO DE 40 Y SUS 5 HIJOS DE 3-7-15-17 Y 19 AÑOS DE EDAD. LA SRA. T. TRABAJA COMO AGENTE MUNICIPAL DE DICHA COMUNIDAD Y SU ESPOSO EL CO DEUDOR ES EL ENCARGADO DE LA MATERNIDAD DE CHANCHOS EN LA AGROPECUARIA C Y M. NO HAY COMPETENCIA PORQUE AMBOS SON EMPLEADOS FIJOS Y SEGUROS; UNO PUBLICO Y EL OTRO PRIVADO, DONDE PERCIBEN SALARIOS MENSUALES. LA SRA. MARTINA INVIRTIO TODO SU CREDITO EN LA COMPRA DE MATERIALES DE CONSTRUCCION. ESTE SERIA EL QUINTO PRESTAMO DE DOÑA MARTINA Y TODOS LOS ANTERIORES LOS A CANCELADO PUNTUALMENTE. ELLA NO TIENE DEUDA EN NINGUNA OTRA FINANCIERA.
texts.en:
Martina is 35 years old and lives in her own home in the community of Azuzaqui together with her husband, who is 40 years old, and their five children, who are 3,7, 15, 17 and 19 years old. She works as a municipal agent in Azuzaqui, and her husband, the co-debtor, is in charge of raising pigs in the CyM Co-op. There is no competition between them as both have secure employment, one in the public sector and the other in the private sector, and they both receive monthly salaries. Martina has invested all of her money in buying construction material. This will be the fifth loan she has received, and she has punctually repaid all of the previous loans. She does not owe money to any other financial institution.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en: Alice K. is the chairperson of Samuka group in Lugazi. She is 39 years of age and married with 4 children. Her retail shop is located right at her home and she is lucky that she does not have to spend money on rent. In her shop she sells cereals, bread, sugar, tea leaves, salt, soap, flour and many more items. This being the rainy season and the time for going back to school, cereals and stationery are selling like hot cakes. She needs a loan to be able to buy a sack of beans, maize, books, pens, and pencils for her shop.

loans.use: Products for her retail shop such as a sack of beans, maize, books, pens, and pencils

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose J. is currently in the business of selling beans, onions and maize flour and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Rose is 25 years old, married and her husband is a security guard. She has 1 child who goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay for her child's school fees  BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business and pay school fees

loans.name: Aïda

texts.fr: Aïda T. est une femme marie qui fait la restauration chez elle. Elle faisait partie d’un groupement mais actuellement elle a ouvert son compte à l’IMCEC Thiès. Ce crédit lui permet de renforcer son activité de restauration c'est-à-dire vendre du fraiche aussi en période de chaleur. Elle est mère de trois enfants, avec ses revenues elle peut aider son mari sur la scolarité de celles-ci.
texts.en:
Aïda T. is a married women who is a restauranteur out of her home. She used to belong to a solidarity group, but at the present time, she has opened her own account at IMCEC Thiès. This loan will enable her to enhance her restaurant business, that is, to sell cold items as well when the weather is hot. She is the mother of three children. With her revenues, she can help her husband with the schooling costs of the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To enhance her restaurant

loans.name: Jose Ibraham

texts.es: el sr. Jose C. tiene 60 años de edad es casado con la sra. Santos Cabrera con la cual procreo dos hijos los cuales estan en los Estados Unidos, el tiene 4 nietos, el se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una pulperia en la cual le va muy bien, tiene 5 años de tenerla y necesita el credito para poderla surtir, quiere comprar pollo, arroz, azucar, jabon, manteca, su deseo es tener una bodega grande en su casa.
texts.en:
Mr. Jose C., 60, is married to Mrs. Santos Cabrera. They have two children who live in the United States. He has 4 grandchildren. He sells popular consumable items. He has had a mini market for 5 years, and he does very well. He needs a loan to be able to increase his stock. He wants to buy chicken, rice, sugar, ham, and lard. He would like to have a large grocery store in his home.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy hams, soft drinks, churros, candies, rice, sugar, coffe, cinnamon, bread, cookies, salsas, spaghetti, soups, sardines, lard, oil, butter, eggs, tortillas.

loans.name: Fanny Beatriz

texts.en:
Fanny is a member of the Virgen Asunta Village Bank in the town of Urco, located just outside the larger town of Calca and about an hour from the city of Cusco. Fanny is 29 years old and is the single mother of two school-age children. Until recently, Fanny worked in a local restaurant. She decided to quit because of some health problems with ulcers and gastritis. She is now launching her own business selling milk in the plaza of the nearby city of Urubamba. Fanny has two cows of her own, which produce about 20 liters of milk per day. She buys an additional 30 liters from other local farmers. She buys the milk for 1.30 soles (US 42 cents) per liter and resells it for 1.40 soles (US 45 cents) per liter. Fanny works seven days a week at this business. 

Fanny is requesting a loan of 1000 soles (US $325), with which she plans to buy a young calf that will eventually produce milk (in about two years). She has been taking out loans from Asociacion Arariwa for about three years. Her very first loan was for 300 soles (US $95). Fanny has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time.

loans.use: To buy a calf to raise for milk production

loans.name: Rukhsana M. Wakeel Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana baji is a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband name is M. W. and he has a timber-selling business and has four year’s experience.

Rukhsana baji herself runs a clothes-selling business. She sells clothes to her neighbors and relatives and buys from different cities named Lahore and Multna. Rukhsana baji is applying for a loan to buy timber to expand her husband’s business.

Rukhsana baji is the group leader of three other women from her locality:

Jamila baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell.

Noor ilahi baji and Sajida baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.

loans.use: To buy timber to sell

loans.name: Sofia Esperanza

texts.es: La Señora Sofía Esperanza S. T. tiene la edad de 47 años, su estado civil es soltera. Doña Sofía tiene 1 hijo y estudia. La actividad económica de Doña Sofía es una pulpería. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que la ubicación es en su casa de habitación. Doña Sofía ha recibido varios prestamos Fundación León 2000, y esto le ha ayudado a invertir cada día en su negocio. Por lo que sus propósitos son de mantener activo este negocio para que el día de mañana pueda generarle los ingresos necesarios. Es por eso que solicita el financiamiento destinado para capital de trabajo incrementando sus productos como gaseosas, refrescos naturales, pan, golosinas, granos básicos y otros productos de consumo en general. El sueño de Sofía es darle las mejoras necesarias a su vivienda ya que se acerca el invierno y quiere estar preparada.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sofia Esperanza S. Torres is 47 years old, single, has a son and is in school. Sofia's business is a grocery store. She has been running this business from her home for the last 5 years. Doña Sofía has received various loans from Fundacion Leon 2000, which she has invested in her business. Her goal is to continue running this business so that she can continue to have income in the future. For this reason she is requesting this loan, to invest in working capital of her business in the form of merchandise such as sodas, natural beverages, bread, candies, basic grains and other general purpose products. Doña Sofía dreams of making the necessary improvements to her house so that she is prepared when the winter comes.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Adim

texts.en: Adim sells provisions and drinks.  She has been in this business for the past 15 years.  She is 45 years old and married with seven children.  She hopes for the loan of N150,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: Purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Bet

texts.en: Bet C. is a thirty-five-year-old clothing vendor residing in Siem Reap Province. She currently sells clothing for both men and women from her store in the local market. She is married with two children who are enrolled in school. Bet is an energetic woman who never wastes time as she works to earn the money to encourage all her kids to attain the highest levels of education. She has managed her investment carefully and has attracted a large number of clients due to her communication skills.  In order to better meet her customers' demands, she would like a $1000 loan to purchase more clothing to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Luz De La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL 
			LUZ D. LA ESPERANZA

La Alcancia Comunal Luz D. la Esperanza está representada por la presidenta Lorry S. y cursan el noveno ciclo demostrando puntualidad y responsabilidad. Este grupo realiza diferentes actividades relacionadas con el comercio, venta D. comida, costura y manualidades. 

La Sra Lorry tuvo un negocio D. cebicheria que  en su momento le dio muchos beneficios, pero lamentablemente por problemas D. salud tuvo que cerrar su negocio; estos problemas le impedían movilizarse, entonces comenzó  un negocio que le permitia desenvolverse en casa,    fue así  que pudo estudiar algunos cursos D. cosmetología y enfermería, que  le permitió mantener a sus hijos, ya que se había separado  D. su esposo hace varios años. 

AhO. ella tiene toda una cartera D. clientes a los cuales atienD. mensualmente. Además venD. productos para el cuidado del cabello.
Los beneficios que ha obtenido han sido D. mejorar la infraestructura D. su casa y seguir pagando la educación D. sus hijos.

El crédito otorgado a ella y a los demás socios será destinado para la compra D. insumos para los diferentes negocios que tienen cada una.
Y así poder brindarles a sus familias lo indispensable para vivir.
texts.en:
Luz D. Esperanza Community Bank The Luz D. Esperanza Community Bank is represented by its president, Lorry S.. They are in their ninth loan cycle, and they have demonstrated punctuality and responsibility. This group has different activities related to sales like food sales, sewing, and handicrafts. Lorry had a “cevicheria” (a restaurant specializing in ceviche and other seafood dishes), which gave her many benefits. Sadly, she had to close the business for health reasons, which impeded her mobility. She then started a business which allowed her to manage it at home. She could study some courses on cosmetology and nursing. This allowed her to support her children. She separated from her husband several years ago. Now she has a good customer base that she tends to every month. She also sells hair care products. The benefits she has gotten have been to improve the infrastructure of her house and to keep paying for her children’s education. The loan given to her and the other members is to buy supplies for the different businesses that each one of them has. That way they can give their families the necessities of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products

loans.name: Sabino Antonio

texts.pt:
Sabino António T., de 33 anos de idade, natural de Matola, província de Maputo, casado pai de 02 filhos de 09 e 04 anos de idade, os dois vão à escola e vive na casa própria em Boane. Interrompeu os estudos na 10ª classe por motivos profissionais mais tarde concluiu o nível médio. para alem dos filhos biológicos sustenta também um filho adoptivo que vive com ele. 

Nunca mudou da cidade tendo passado toda a sua infância, sua adolescência e a sua juventude na cidade que lhe viu nascer, onde vive ate hoje. Boane.  

Sabino T. é professor na casa do Gaiato (centro de artes e ofícios e orfanato) há nove anos, começou a trabalhar antes de fazer a sua formação profissional, só veio a fazer o curso no Instituto de Magistérios Primarios-Matola há quatro anos tendo como renda mensal de 10.000,00MT com o qual sustenta a família e consegue poupar algum para melhorar a sua residência.

Conheceu a Hluvuku-adsema através de amigos e colegas que também são clientes da instituição e este é o segundo empréstimo, tendo se beneficiado de empréstimo no valor de 12.500,00MT cuja finalidade era compra de material de construção.  Fez o reembolso do primeiro empréstimo sem problemas. 

Com o presente empréstimo de 15.000,00MT pretende comprar cimento, areia e pedra para concluir a sua obra. O seu maior desafio é concluir a obra e sonha em ter outra casa no campo onde poderá programar projectos de agropecuária.
Propõe-se a pagar o credito sem problemas para poder aceder a outros créditos para tornar possível o sonho de ser um empreendedor de sucesso.
texts.en:
Sabino António T., 33, was born in Boane, district of Matola, in the province of Maputo, where he still lives. Married and the father of three school-age kids (two biological and one adopted), Sabino lives with his family in a house they own and that is still under construction. In spite of his high-school studies having been interrupted for a few years due to his need to work to support himself, Sabino was able to go back to school and got his teaching credentials four years ago, from the Instituto de Magistério Primário-Matola (Elementary School Education Institute-Matola). He has been a teacher at "Casa do Gaiato" (orphanage and arts & crafts school) for the past nine years. His monthly salary of 10.000,00 mt allows him to support his family and save some money. Sabino heard about Hluvuku-Adsema from friends. He will be using this, his second loan, to buy construction material to finish his house. He expects to pay this loan back without problems, as he did with the first one. In the future, he hopes to apply for other loans to buy some land where he can build a second home, develop agricultural projects and realize his dream of becoming a successful entrepreneur.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy construction material

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is a thirty five year old mother who lives in Mukuru slums and operates a retail kiosk. She has requested her first loan of Ksh. 20,000 to enable her add stocks of flour, soft drinks and other products. She desires to grow her business into wholesale, buy a piece of land, and educate her children. She describes herself as hardworking, patient and social.


Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing access to financial opportunities. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add to stock

loans.name: Rosario Edith

texts.en:
Rosario is a member of the Sun and Moon village bank
She is 40 years-old, married, and has two children who are 13 and 12. Rosario sells clothes, shoes, perfumes, toys, and many other things that her clients order. 
She started working when she finished school at the age of 16. One day she went to a shop and saw that they were selling perfumes at low prices. She bought the perfumes and sold them. Afterwards she went to other shops and asked for bulk sale prices and increased her sales little by little.  
Rosario and her family also have a little farm in which she invests. Sometimes she uses her loans to buy fertilizers and seeds. After 8 years with FINCA Peru, Rosario says things have changed for the better because now she has her own house and more clients. 
Rosario needs a loan of 1000 soles so that she can invest in more sweatshirts, sheets, summer clothes, shoes, and perfumes. Her dream is to have her own shop when her children are older.

loans.use: more sweatshirts, sheets, summer clothes, shoes, and perfumes.

loans.name: Gaudance

texts.en:
Gaudance N. is 32 years old,single and she takes care of 3 children aged between 8 and 2.
she lives in kicukiro district,kigali province capital of Rwanda.
she does the business of salon since 2003,and she employs six persons in her business,starting everyday from 6h00 AM to 9h00 PM.

before this business she could get all needs for her family becouse she was fultime house wife.

with this new loan requested in vision finance,she plans to expand her business through purchasing new equipment in order to get more profits .

loans.use: purchase more materiels

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 46 years old and married with seven children. She sells fruits like bananas to make a living and has been in this business for fourteen years.

Agnes hopes for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more fruit to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie B. is from the village of Bacator Tangub City. She is 41 years old. Rosemarie is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Rosemarie owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products and dried goods in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosemarie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosemarie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
This is Zenaida M. from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  She is a mother to four children. All but one of her children study in different school levels.  Her husband Stephen is a freelance videographer/photographer.

Zenaida manages a photo/video coverage studio.  She negotiates with clients while her husband does the actual video/photo coverage.  They cover different functions like weddings, birthdays, graduation ceremonies and other family oriented activities.  Zenaida’s net monthly income from the studio is P10,000.00.  She is happy that her profits can answer the technical needs of their business although she laments that some clients fail to redeem their photos from the studio and so are just stocked up in their archives, which translates to business losses.

Zenaida currently needs a loan of P30,000.00 to purchase some of their studio’s technical requirements like digital flash for the cameras and batteries.  This will be her 14th loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy technical equipment for photography (digital flash, batteries,etc.)

loans.name: Edita

texts.es:
La señora Edita, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Nazarenas”, Distrito de Bellavista, Provincia de Bellavista, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 38 años y es madre de 02 hijos, 02 que aun dependen de ella. 

Edita, es una mujer que le gusta trabajar, así que decidió poner su propio negocio de ventas de bebidas gasificadas, ubicada en su misma casa, en un local muy bien acondicionado. Es ella misma quien administra su negocio, sin tener un horario y un jefe. Nos cuenta que se inicio con S/. 300.00 y empezó comprando 05 paquetes de gaseosas,  vio que le iba muy bien y que le falto sus gaseosas, poco a poco fue invirtiendo mas. En la Actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio y ya es conocida por sus clientes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200.00, comprará mas bebidas como gaseosas en diferentes sabores, tamaños y marcas como también agua mineral con gas y sin gas.
 
Edita, tiene muchas metas por delante y se siente motivada por hacer realidad  lo que se propone. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla cuando mas lo necesitaba, es responsable con sus cuotas de pago y piensa seguir así.
texts.en:
The Señora Edita belongs to the Communal Bank "Las Nazarenas", an affiliate of Kiva, in the District of Bellavista, Province of Bellavista, Department of San Martín. She is married, 38 years old, and is the mother of two children, both of whom depend on her. Edita is a woman who likes to work, which is why she decided to start her own business selling carbonated soda, located in her own house, in a very good location. She herself administers her business, without having a schedule or a boss. She tells us that she started with S/. 300, and began buying five packages of carbonated drinks, but saw that they sold very well and that she ran out of supplies, but little by little she invested more. Currently, she is continuing this business and is known by her clients. With this loan of S/. 1,200, she will buy more carbonated drinks in different flavors, sizes, and brands, like mineral water and bottled water. Edita has many goals in front of her and she feels motivated to make what she proposes a reality. She is very grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping her when she needed it most, is responsible for her repayment, and thinks she will continue to be.

Translated from Spanish by Lois Parshley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soda.

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
La señora JUSTINA, pertenece al Banco Comunal “HUAYNA CCAPAC” de la Asociación Arariwa de la Provincia del Cusco del Departamento del Cusco. La socia tiene 68 años es madre soltera y tiene cuatro hijos.  

Su carácter y su anhelo de cumplir sus sueños, le motivó abrir hace varios años su propio negocio de venta de empanadas en el colegio “Arturo Palomino”, cuyas ganancias aporta al ingreso económico en su hogar. La socia de lunes a viernes esta en el negocio de las empanadas y los fines de semana en la plaza “Tupac Amaru” del distrito de Wanchaq vende accesorios de herramientas de jardinería. Ya son varios años en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia a pesar de las adversidades. La socia requiere el préstamo para adquirir más herramientas como palas, picos y tijeras.  

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
JUSTINA, 68, is a member of Asociación Arariwa's “HUAYNA CCAPAC” communal bank which is located in Cusco province, Cusco department. She is a single mother of 4 children. Her wish to see her dreams come true and her way of being motivated her to open her own business several years ago; she sells empanadas (turnovers) at the "Arturo Palomino" school. The earnings from these sales go to her household expenses. She sells the empanadas from Monday through Friday and on weekends sells gardening tools in “Tupac Amaru” plaza in Wanchaqu district. She has been in this line of work for several years, too and has done well, thanks to the efforts she puts into it. She is a hard-working, enterprising woman who sees to it that her family gets ahead in life despite all adversities. She needs funding to buy more gardening tools like shovels, pickaxes and shears. She is grateful for the opportunity granted by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy gardening tools.

loans.name: El Alacaraban Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Alacaraban está conformado por tres mujeres que desde su juventud han trabajado para ganarse el sustento y mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.  Josefa del Carmen M. comenzó a vender frutas a la edad de 20 años, ella asegura que en sus inicios su comercio era muy reducido pero actualmente  luego de 20 años compra y vende por mayor.

Ana Nubia M. G. desde 19979 vende frutas y verduras en el mercado de Masaya el cual poco a poco ha crecido y Ziria de los Ángeles T. M. desde muy joven empezó a comercializar frutas de acuerdo a la temporada.  

En este  nuevo año que inicia invertirán en cítricos como naranjas, mandarina que tiene gran demanda en está temporada.
texts.en:
The Alacaraban Group is made up of three women who have been working since they were young to earn a living and improve their families' quality of life. Josefa de Carmen M. started selling fruit when she was twenty. She assures us that while her business started out very small, now, twenty years later, she buys and sells wholesale. Ana Nubia M. G. has been selling fruit since 1979 in the Masaya market, which has grown little by little. Ziria de los Ángeles T. M. began selling seasonal fruits when she was very young. In the coming new year they will invest in citrus fruits like oranges and tangerines, which are in high demand this time of year.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy produce

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa T. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling food and daily use products in her community. She is married and has one school-age child. They are from the village of Langcata-on, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. Marissa has been in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Marissa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marissa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Marissa is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
LA SEÑORA MARGARITA TIENE UNA TIENDA DE BARRIO, QUE ES UNA ESPECIE DE ALMACEN PEQUEÑO, EN LA ZONA DE ALTO SAN ISIDRO. ELLA VIVE JUNTO A SU HIJA QUE SE ENCUENTRA EN EDAD ESCOLAR. MARGARITA ES UNA PERSONA CONOCIDA Y RESPETADA EN SU BARRIO YA QUE ES MUY AMABLE Y BRINDA UNA BUENA ATENCIÓN A TODOS SUS CLIENTES. ELLA ADEMÁS ES CONSIDERADA UNA BUENA MADRE YA QUE ELLA ESTA DIVORCIADA Y A PESAR DE ESO HA CRIADO A SU HIJA CON UNA BUENA EDUCACIÓN Y MUCHO CARIÑO. MARGARITA SOLICITA EL CRÉDITO PARA PODER INCREMENTAR EL CAPITAL DE SU TIENDA YA QUE COMPRARÁ MATERIAL ESCOLAR POR QUE SE APROXIMA EL COMIENZO DE CLASES Y TENDRÁ MUCHOS PEDIDOS. UNO DE LOS MAYORES DESEOS DE ELLA ES VER A SU HIJA COMO UNA PROFESIONAL.

ESTA AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Mrs. Margarita has a neighborhood store. This is a type of small shop, in the Alto San Isidro area. She lives together with her school-aged daughter. Margarita is popular and respected in her neighborhood because she is very friendly and gives a lot of attention to all of her customers. Also she is considered to be a good mother. Despite being divorced, she has raised her daughter with much affection and has taught her to have good manners. Margarita is asking for the loan so that she can increase the capital for her store. She will buy school supplies because the start of classes is coming and she will have many orders. One of her biggest wishes is to see her daughter become a professional. She is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust offered her in granting her the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school supplies

loans.name: Akingbala

texts.en:
T. is 45 years old, married, and has four children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells clothes, shoes and bags to her customers at retail prices. She will use her loan to invest in her clothing business by buying in bulk to get a better price. T. hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children.
She is excited to be taking a loan with Kiva partner, LAPO, and thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes and bags

loans.name: Lorgenia

texts.en:
Lorgenia S. is from the village of Malibangcao, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old and is single. Lorgenia owns and operates a business planting and harvesting coconuts for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Lorgenia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lorgenia is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna has been selling tubers of yam for the past ten years. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Yams in Nigeria can be eaten boiled, fried and roasted. 

Anna is married with four children. Her husband is a pastor and he also supports their home.

She asks for a loan amount of 120,000 NGN to purchase more tubers of yams to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en: D. Shuhrat is a simple farmer with simple dreams – to uplift his family’s economic life and, in future, be able to send his dearest little son to school. Farming has been Shuhrat’s major source of income; he produces rice once a year. Because of the expensive farm inputs, traders buy their rice products at too low a price. Because of this, he requests a loan of 700 USD to support his farming business and to avoid asking for credit from traders with higher interest rates. Shuhrat is grateful that he is able to borrow from lenders that offer lower interest rates, allowing borrowers to create better opportunities in their lives - thus, helping their families to be free from poverty. Shuhrat said that, through prayers and hard work, his dreams can be achieved someday. Providing his son with education is one of the important things that Shuhrat prioritizes. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Soraya

texts.es: La Sra. Soraya se dedica a la Compra , Reacondicionamiento y Venta de Peluches de diferentes formas y tamaños, ella realiza la adquisición de los mismos por fardos en la conocida Feria de la Cumavi, su oficio consiste en reacomodar todos aquellos peluches que llegan dañados, colocandoles nueva fibra y labando el envoltorio, posterior a la realización de estas mejoras y otras, los peluches son envolsados y puestos nuevamente a la venta con diferentes precios de acuerdo al tamaño y las caracteristicas mejoradas de los mismos. Doña Soraya cuenta con créditos anteriores en la Institución donde demostro ser puntual en sus cuotas motivo por el cual se le otorgó este nuevo crédito, además de eso ella cuenta con domicilio conocido en la Villa 1ro de Mayo. Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Soraya buys, reconditions, and sells all different shapes and sizes of stuffed animals. She gets them in bundles at the well-known Cumavi Fair. Her work consists of reassembling all of the stuffed animals that arrive damaged. She puts in new stuffing and washes the outside. After making these improvements, and others, the stuffed animals are bagged and put up for sale again. They are different prices according to their size and the improvements that were made. Soraya has had previous loans with the Institución. She was punctual with her payments, which is why she was given this new loan. She lives in the Villa 1ro de Mayo. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence given in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Maria Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Maria Rosario C. es socia del banco comunal Mujeres de Trabajo vive en la vecina ciudad de Azogues o San Francisco de Peleusí de Azogues,  es la capital de la provincia del Cañar que  por su ubicación  topográfica es una ciudad bien asoleada desde el punto Este culminante en el  Santuario Franciscano sobre todo en las horas de mas sol produciendo fuertes contrastes  en el sector urbano-arquitectonico, además podemos disfrutar de las belleza de las grandes inclinaciones hasta el cajón del río Burgay.

Nuestra socia tiene 37 años de edad, es madre soltera de tres hijos quienes se encuentran de 19, 15 y 11 años de edad, su primera hija trabaja y le ayuda económicamente con el arriendo de la casa y  los estudios de sus hermanos menores que  son estudiantes de secundaria y primaria respectivamente en instituciones de la ciudad,  no recibe ningún apoyo por parte del progenitor de sus  hijos y entre ella y su hija sacan adelante su familia.

María Rosario es comerciante de periódico y billetes de lotería actividad que realiza hace 12 años, trabaja todos los días sin descansar uno solo,  labora desde las 8 a.m. hasta las 4 p.m. y este ya es como un negocio familiar. Se encuentra en su segundo ciclo trabajando con su banco comunal gracias a que fue invitada por su hermana, con su crédito comprará más  billetes de lotería.

Su meta es crecer mas en su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria Rosario C. is a member of the community bank "Mujeres de Trabajo". She lives in the neighboring city of Azogues, or otherwise known by its full name San Francisco de Peleusi de Azogues. It is the provincial captial of Canar, that by its geography is a very sunny city. On the eastern-most point is the Franciscan sanctuary whose achictecture is strongly contrasted at high noon, in addition they enjoy the beauty of the great mountains spanning to the canyon of the Burgay river. Our member is 37 years old and she is a single mother of three children aged 19, 15 and 11 years old. Her eldest daughter works and helps her financially with the maintenance of the hosue and with her sibilings' education. They attend high school and primary school in the city. She does not receive any kind of support from the father of the children so it is only up to her and her daughter to take care of the family. Maria Rosario sells newspapers and lottery tickets. It is a business she has been running for the past 12 years. She works every day without ever taking a day to rest. She works from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. on this business that has become the family business. She is seeking her second loan through her community bank, following an invitation by her sister to join. This loan will be invested in the purchase of more lottery tickets.. Her goal is to expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase lottery tickets.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame T. is single and sells clothes in Takoradi. She has received senior high education. Maame uses her earnings to pay for her rent and utility bills. Maame will use this loan to purchase more clothes to sell to improve her business. Maame plans to add the new profits from her expanded business to her capital.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Juana Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Juana Mercedes A. P., tiene la edad de 55 años vive en el barrio la Borgoña, tiene 3 hijos y es madre soltera, todos sus hijos son mayores de edad, trabajan y viven de forma independiente, así mismo apoyan a su madre en los gastos y actividades en su hogar, ella es una mujer muy humilde que realiza trabajos domésticos en casas privadas, tiene alrededor de 15 años de ganarse de esta manera el sustento diarios de toda su familia.

Con el apoyo económico de sus hijos es que logró componer su habitación personal, a futuro espera tener los recursos necesarios para remodelar en su totalidad su hogar, por ahora solicita de un préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción que le permitan terminar de componer el patio trasero de su hogar, es importante señalar que esta inversión les traerá un beneficio a toda la familia a habitar en un ambiente más salubre, seguro y cómodo.
texts.en:
Juana Mercedes Aguirre P., 55, lives in the La Borgoña neighborhood. She is a single mother who has 3 adult children who are working and living independently. They help out their mother with the household expenses and activities. She is a very unassuming woman who works as a domestic in private residences. She has been doing this work for about 15 years, and it has allowed her to support herself and her family. With the economic support of her children she managed to fix up her own personal living space. In the future she hopes to have the resources necessary to renovate her whole home, but for now she requests a loan to buy construction materials that will permit her to finish repairing the patio at the back of her home. It is important to note that this investment will bring a benefit to the whole family, so that they can live in an environment that is healthier, secure and comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to repair a patio at the back of her home

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros S. is from the village of Linabu, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Milagros is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Milagros owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Milagros joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Milagros from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jean Franklin

texts.es:
Jean tiene 20 años de edad, es soltero y vive junto a un familiar en el sector Pacangilla, un centro poblado pequeño ubicado en el distrito de Pacanga, una zona agrícola pertenciente a la provincia de Chepén, ubicada en la región La Libertad, situada a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a brindar servicio de transporte de carga y pasajeros en una mototaxi (vehículo motorizado consistente en una motocicleta que lleva anexada una cabina para realizar actividades de transporte) el brinda su servicio dentro de su centro poblado y del distrito donde vive, adicionalmente transporta petróleo para las diversas maquinarias agrícolas que operan en los centros poblados de la zona. Con los ingresos que percibe de estas actividades el solventa sus gastos personales y apoya a sus familiares con el sostenimiento de la economía familiar.

El contínuo uso brindado a la mototaxi que maneja y el estado accidentado de los caminos que suele transitar han hecho que su unidad móvil empiece a sufrir algunas fallas que requieren de urgente reparación para garantizar su correcto funcionamiento, para realizar esta acción el ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1200 nuevos soles.

Jean es un joven bastante emprendedor y que siempre da lo mejor de si para salir adelante y poder progresar, en la zona donde vive sus vecino y conocidos le consideran una persona tranquila y responsable.
texts.en:
Jean is 20, single and lives with a family member in the Pacangilla sector, a small, crowded center located in the Pacanga district. Pacanga is an agricultural zone belonging to the Chepen province, located in the La Libertad region, one hour from the city of Chiclayo. Chiclayo is the capital of the Lambayeque region. Jean offers a transportation service for cargo an passengers in a mototaxi (a motorized vehicle consisting of a motorcycle with an attached cabin for transport activities). He offers his service in the populated center of the city in which he lives. He also transports oil for the various agricultural machinery that operate in the area. With his income he covers his personal costs and supports his family members with household costs. The constant use of the mototaxi that he drives and the rough state of the roads on which he drives have caused some problems for his mototaxi that require urgent repair to guarantee proper functioning. In order to do this he has requested his first loan with Edpyme Alternativa: 1200 soles. Jean is a very enterprising young man who always gives his best to succeed and progress. In his neighbourhood his neighbours and acquaintances consider him to be a calm and responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: repair and maintenance costs for a mototaxi

loans.name: Asri Lestari Group

texts.en:
Ni Nyoman L. M. is a 32-year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali.  Ni Nyoman L. M. is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Asri Lestari (PK-10251).

Ni Nyoman L. M. is married and has two school-aged children.  To making a living, Ni Nyoman L. M. owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale.  Ni Nyoman L. M. has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2010, Ni Nyoman L. M. joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Nyoman L. M. is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK. She is now requesting a new loan of 1,200,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  The loan will be the first loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Nyoman L. M. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About MUK:
The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Francisco Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Francisco A. labora como mensajero en UNICA, es casado , tiene 4 personas a su cargo, 
Es el primer crédito que se le otorga el cual será utilizado para pagos de aranceles escolares y para realizar exámenes de un hijo que esta enfermo.
texts.en:
Francisco A. works as a messenger for UNICA [Catholic University]. He is married and has 4 people who are dependent on him. This is the first loan that is being granted to him. He will use it to pay school fees and also to undertake some medical exams for one of his children, who is ill.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying school fees for his children and undertaking medical exams for one child

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma S. is from the town of Talibon. She is 25 years old. Guillerma is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Guillerma owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from gathering and selling seaweed to the market. Guillerma also runs a small sari-sari store where she sells a variety of different products.

Guillerma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Guillerma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Guillerma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets and additional store inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets and additional store inventory.

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn M., from the village of Brgy. Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao, is 31 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jovelyn has been raising pigs for breeding for over three years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Jovelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 15000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase breeding livestock, she is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Jovelyn's sixth loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon M. is from the village of Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City. She is 43 years old. Corazon is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Corazon runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products like milk, coffee, soft drinks breads and other food products in the local community. Aside from that, she also has a karaoke machine that will play song for customers who wants to sing for only 5 PHP. Corazon has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000  (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Corazon joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Corazon from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve his house. To buy cement and iron to finish a wall

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
La señora Silvia vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la ciudad de La Paz, casada tiene un hijo, trabaja en una tienda vendiendo joyas como empleada.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar oro y plata y elaborar joyas con su familia, pues tienen experiencia en este tipo de trabajo, para de esta manera poner su propio negocio y mejorar sus ingresos.

Es cliente de Impro ya fue parte de Kiva; paga muy bien por lo tanto puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Silvia lives in her parents’ house in the Villa Nuevo Potosí zone of the city of La Paz.  She is married, has one child, and is a jewelry store employee.

She is requesting this loan to buy gold and silver to make jewelry with her family, as they have experience in this type of work.  This would allow her to start her own business and improve her income.

She is a client of Impro and already a Kiva participant; she repays her loans properly, which has allowed her access to credit again.

loans.use: To buy gold and silver for making jewelry to then sell.

loans.name: Ayaz

texts.en:
Ayaz Q. is a 27-year-old man who lives in Sabirabad.  He is married and has one son. In 2007, Ayaz started his animal breeding business. His wife helps him in this business, which is the only source of income for their family. 

This is his first loan from Aqroinvest and Kiva. Ayaz used the 1000 AZN loan to buy two more cows. After repaying this loan, he plans to apply for another loan from Aqroinvest to buy four more cows.

loans.use: To buy two more cows

loans.name: Sérieux Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sérieux est un constitué de cinq femmes qui vivent dans le même quartier, Darsalam de la ville de Koutiala, dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et coépouses. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 3 enfants.
Ce groupe sérieux fait l’achat et la vente de produits cosmétiques, d’habillements  de  bois de chauffe et des fruits et légumes.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles viennent d’avoir leur premier prêt de groupe.  
Awa Kamaté,  qui est la présidente du groupe fait l’achat et la vente des habillements.  Elle est très sollicitée car elle occupe une bonne place au marché de Darsalam.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des habits de différentes sortes. Elle se procure de ces marchandises au  grand marché de Koutiala en gros pour les  revendre en détail  au comptant et a crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement  de  femmes.
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Sérieux comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 55 000FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Awa Kamaté  elle,  compte réaliser 65 000 FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.

Ce groupe sérieux fait l’achat et la vente de produits cosmétiques, d’habillements  de  bois de chauffe et des fruits et légumes.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles viennent d’avoir leur premier prêt de groupe.  
Awa Kamaté,  qui est la présidente du groupe fait l’achat et la vente des habillements.  Elle est très sollicitée car elle occupe une bonne place au marché de Darsalam.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des habits de différentes sortes. Elle se procure de ces marchandises au  grand marché de Koutiala en gros pour les  revendre en détail  au comptant et a crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement  de  femmes.
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Sérieux comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 55 000FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Awa Kamaté  elle,  compte réaliser 65 000 FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en: The Sérieux group consists of five women who live in the same neighborhood, Darsalam, in the city of Koutiala. They live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and co-wives. On average, they are 42 years old, married and have at least 3 children.The Sérieux  group buys and sells cosmetics, clothing, firewood and fruits and vegetables.  In order to expand their businesses, the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. They just had their first group loan.  Awa Kamaté, who is the leader of the group, buys and sells clothing.    She is in high demand because she is located at a good place at the Darsalam market.  She plans to use her loan to buy different kinds of clothing. She obtains these goods wholesale at the Koutiala Grand Market and sells them retail for cash and credit to a largely female clientele. While the other Sérieux group members expect to make a profit of 55,000 CFA each during this cycle, Awa Kamaté expects to make 65,000 CFA.  As well as repaying the loans, they use  part of their  income to provide for their families’ everyday expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing

loans.name: El Oasis 1 Group

texts.es: Esta foto fue tomada en la casa de Judith una integrante del grupo El Oasis 1 que está ubicado en el Estado de Veracruz en México. Se ve al grupo de señoras alrededor de la mecancía en la foto. Ella se dedica a la venta de muebles y bisutería que inicio hace 1 año. Solicita el préstamo para invertir en material para bisuteria y segir invirtiendo en su negocio de muebles. Al momento de solicitar este préstamo se siente contenta y satisfecha. Tiene 21 años, estudió hasta 3er. semestre de preparatoria, vive en unión libre y tiene en total 1 hijo varón de 2 años. Tambien espera poder incrementar más sus ventas y poder darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
This photo was taken in Judith's home.  Judith is a member of the El Oasis 1 group which is located in the State of Veracruz in Mexico.  Here in the photo you can see the ladies surrounding her merchandise.  Judith sells furniture and jewelry.  She started her business one year ago.

Judith is requesting a loan to invest in material for making jewelry and to keep her furniture business running.  At the time of requesting this loan she feels happy and satisfied.  She is 21 years and studied up to the third semester of high school.  She lives with her common-law husband and has a 2 year-old son.  She hopes to be able to further increase her sales and provide her family with a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy furniture and jewelry

loans.name: Louise

texts.en: Louise owns a bar. She is 26 years old, married and has three children. Louise and her husband work together in the same business. Louise has been working in a bar for five years. Her loan will be used to add more beer and sodas to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy more beer to sell

loans.name: Adriana

texts.es: La Sra.
